message_1: Calculate the Gibbs free energy change at standard conditions for the following synthesis reaction: CO2 (g) + 2H2 (g) → CH3OH (g)
message_2:
To calculate the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG°) at standard conditions for the given reaction, we need to know the standard Gibbs free energy of formation (ΔGf°) for each of the compounds involved in the reaction. The standard Gibbs free energy of formation is the change in Gibbs free energy when 1 mole of a compound is formed from its constituent elements in their standard states.

The reaction is: CO2 (g) + 2H2 (g) → CH3OH (g)

The standard Gibbs free energy of formation for the compounds involved are:

ΔGf° (CO2) = -394.4 kJ/mol
ΔGf° (H2) = 0 kJ/mol (since H2 is an element in its standard state)
ΔGf° (CH3OH) = -162.2 kJ/mol

Now, we can calculate the Gibbs free energy change for the reaction using the following equation:

ΔG° = Σ [ΔGf° (products)] - Σ [ΔGf° (reactants)]

ΔG° = [ΔGf° (CH3OH)] - [ΔGf° (CO2) + 2 * ΔGf° (H2)]

ΔG° = (-162.2 kJ/mol) - (-394.4 kJ/mol + 2 * 0 kJ/mol)

ΔG° = -162.2 kJ/mol + 394.4 kJ/mol

ΔG° = 232.2 kJ/mol

The Gibbs free energy change at standard conditions for the given synthesis reaction is 232.2 kJ/mol.
